title: International students choosing to study in Wellington over other parts of country
text:
International students choosing to study in Wellington over other parts of country JARED NICOLL Last updated 20:09, February 27 2017 WREDA 
Margaret Ortega, left, from Hong Kong, says she loves Wellington because it's big enough that you are never bored, but small enough that you can walk most places. 
Wellington is increasingly becoming the destination of choice for international students, and the city cashed in to the tune of almost $200 million during the first eight months of last year. 
The number of international students who enrolled to study in the capital grew 12 per cent between January and August 2016, compared to 10 per cent in Auckland and nine per cent nationally. 
Wellington secondary schools saw their international students increase by 29 per cent, polytechs saw a 16 per cent increase, and university enrolments were up six per cent. SUPPLIED 
Shankar Narayanan, from India, says that, compared to India, the people of Wellington recognise and consider who you are and what you want to be. 
That increase of 770 students brought the total number studying in the capital up to about 7000. 
READ MORE: 
Data from Immigration NZ showed the largest amount of student visas went to students from China followed by India. SUPPLIED 
Pierre-Emmanuel Martin de Marolles, from France, says going to the beach and walking around Mt Victoria and Zealandia are his favourite things about Wellington. 
In total, international students contributed about $198m to the Wellington regional economy in the 2015-16 financial year. 
Wellington city councillor Nicola Young, who holds the Education Partnerships portfolio, said the influx of overseas students "boosts our economy and increases our cosmopolitan vibe, and expands our international networks.” 
The Wellington Regional Economic Development Agency (Wreda) is one of a number of agencies involved in delivering the Wellington International Student Growth Programme, a multi-year initiative designed to increase the amount of international fee-paying students in the region. SUPPLIED 
Wainuiomata High School Year 12 student Ryo Asada enjoys watching the sea and enjoying nature in Wellington – something she says she can’t do this in Tokyo. 
The initiatives sells Wellington overseas as a place with an affordable lifestyle, part-time work opportunities and smaller immigrant communities, meaning students end up speaking English more and improve it faster. 
Wreda chief executive Chris Whelan said the programme, founded in 2015, engaged over 100 agents with links to 12 countries in its first year, to increase their awareness of Wellington’s education offering. 
Scots College headmaster Graeme Yule said international students brought "global perspectives" into classroom discussions. SUPPLIED 
Alice Lau Cheuk Ying, from Hong Kong, says she likes Wellington because the people are helpful. 
"Our local students' horizons are broadened, and friendships are often formed, which give our students contacts and connections around the world in years to come." 
The Government announced a target in 2010 to lift the economic value of international education in New Zealand to $5 billion by 2025. 
MARGARET ORTEGA 
Came to Wellington from Hong Kong to study a Bachelor of Commerce in Commercial Law & International Business at Victoria University. The best thing about studying in Wellington was that it is a big enough city that you are never bored, but small enough that you can walk most places. "I love being able to get in my car and drive a few hours to snowboard or be surrounded by the most beautiful environments. Her favourite thing to do in Wellington when not studying was "eat or explore". But she did miss the "delicious" dim sum back home, as well as "the hustle and bustle of a big city and my friends". 
SHANKAR NARAYANAN 
Came to Wellington from India to study a Graduate Diploma in Creative Technologies at WelTec. The best thing about studying in Wellington was exposure to top companies, as well as the Kiwi culture, he said. "Compared to India, people recognise and consider who you are and what you want to be. They don’t consider your past, your history. I love that concept." His favourite thing to do in Wellington when not studying was walking along the waterfront and fishing in Oriental Bay. The thing he missed most about home was the food. "This is always going to be my answer. Friends and family too, but my mum’s food is the best. It is heaven." 
ALICE LAU CHEUK YING 
Came to Wellington from Hong Kong to study at Yoobee school of design. Her favourite thing about studying in Wellington was the people, who she described as helpful and nice. "They are glad to help me getting used to the living environment around here. Also I love the artistic atmosphere here, which is good for my inspiration." The thing about home that she missed the most was her family and my friends in Hong Kong. "But luckily we can communicate by social network platforms." Her favourite things to do in Wellington when not studying was exploring museums and window shopping with friends around Courtenay Place. 
PIERRE-EMMANUEL MARTIN DE MAROLLES 
Came to Wellington from France to study English at The Campbell Institute. The best thing about studying in Wellington was meeting students from different countries and learn different cultures," he said. "Wellington is a small city so you can go everywhere by foot and there are a lot of parks to relax in after studying." His favourite thing to do when not studying was going to the beach and walking in the city especially around Mt Victoria and Zealandia. "I also like to go to the Cuba St pubs and support The Hurricanes at Westpac Stadium." Apart from French food, especially baguettes, there was not a lot he missed about home. 
RYO ASADA 
Came to Wellington from Japan to study at Wainuiomata High School, where she is a Year 12 student. The best things about living in the Wellington region was the environment, which she said was very natural. "And the people are friendly and kind." her favourite thing to do favourite thing to do in Wellington when not studying was shopping for clothes and food on Lambton Quay, as well as watching the sea and enjoying the nature. "Can’t do this in Tokyo," she said. "I also enjoyed kayaking along the Wellington Waterfront." The thing about home she missed the most was the food, in particular sushi and rice. "It tastes different at home. I miss my friends at home but just a little bit." - Stuff
